ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Vested interests of owners and management staff)


    1. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications if he has been informed by the owners and management staff of the Singapore Bus

Column: 710

Service (Private) Limited of their vested interests in finance, insurance, motor garages, motor repair shops, petrol service stations, tyre shops, motor spare part shops and other concerns which have dealings with the Company; and if he has taken all possible steps to ensure that there are no contrivances of irregular and improper practices amongst such business concerns which may be considered to be against the public interest.

Column: 711



    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Sir, as there are no statutory requirements under the Companies Act (Chapter 185) or the Bus Services Licensing Authority Act, 1971, for owners and management staff of the Singapore Bus Service Ltd to declare to the Ministry of Communications "their vested interests in finance, insurance, motor garages, motor repair shops, petrol service stations, tyre shops, motor spare part shops and other concerns which have dealings with SBS", before SBS was issued with licences to operate on the approved routes under the Bus Services Licensing Authority Act, there was no cause for them to inform me of their interests, if any.

    However, during the course of the weekly meetings of the Bus Services Reorganisation Committee (BSRC) since October, 1973, SBS's interests in two companies which appear to have a bearing on SBS operations did come to my notice, namely:-

    (a) At the BSRC meeting on 18th December, 1973, information was given that two directors of Green Bus Company, which Company constitutes part of the United Bus Co, and which in turn forms a component part of SBS, would appear to be closely associated with Soon Chow Corpn. (Pte) Ltd which is known to build the bodywork of many new buses for SBS.

    (b) On 19th March, 1974, information was made available to the BSRC that the Managing Director of SBS is also a Director of Inter-Island Transport Maintenance (Pte) Ltd, which was formed to enable SBS to maintain its fleet of buses as well as to purchase spare parts more expeditiously and get on with the early repair of a large part of its immobilised bus fleet, as the present method of ordering spare parts through agents of 17 different makes of buses proved unsatisfactory because of great price fluctuations and also inability to deliver on schedule for the orders made.

    In view of the fact that one of the conditions for the bus fare revision authorised by my Ministry on 10th February, 1974, has fixed a ceiling to the annual profits which SBS would be

Column: 712

allowed to earn over the next three years (namely, 8% of its net assets, i.e, net book value of Buses less Hire purchase obligations) as certified by its auditors, BSRC has since been instructed to request all shareholders and senior management staff who have the authority to make purchases or authorise repairs and services for SBS to make such declarations of their interests in related business, to the Bus Services Licensing Authority within one month. Amending legislation will be introduced soon, to make such declarations mandatory.

    The Member for Kallang can be assured that all reasonable steps will be taken by my Ministry to ensure that SBS and its associated companies, when disclosed, will conduct their activities in a proper and business-like manner, and should any action against public interest be discovered whoever responsible will be suitably dealt with under the law.

    Finally, the Member for Kallang may be aware that present legislation requires Directors of Companies to make full disclosure of their respective interests at meetings when contracts with the company are being dealt with, under section 131 of the Companies Act (Cap. 185). Failure on the part of directors to disclose such material interests, if brought to the notice of the Registrar of Companies, can render the person liable for appropriate penalties under the Companies Act.

    Head LK --

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head LK be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AA 1107*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, it cannot be denied that in the past few years the Primary Production Department has made useful contributions towards the promotion of agriculture. For instance, the Department has introduced the immunisation of poultry, the introduction of fine breeds and also the teaching of modern and scientific methods of agriculture and poultry-keeping so as to benefit the farmers. However, we are faced with the basic problem, namely, the shortage of land for agriculture development. Therefore, we have to depend on import of vegetables, fish, and other foods for which we have to pay foreign exchange. Because of this, the yearly foreign exchange that we spend amounts to several hundreds of millions of dollars.

    Sir, in view of world-wide inflation and high prices I feel that the Primary Production Department should take up more responsibility in the provision of daily necessities so as to enable our people to buy goods at reasonable prices. In what fields can the Primary Production Department be of any service? I feel there are three aspects of work which it can do: (1) the extensive planting of certain vegetables, including potatoes and mushrooms, in some villages or in certain islands so as to lower the cost of agricultural products; (2) to develop fresh water fish breeding and deep-sea fishing so as to save some tens of million dollars on foreign exchange: and, (3) to develop a tropical fish market on a large scale in order to get a substantial amount of foreign exchange for our country. At this time of inflation I feel that these schemes would contribute towards national savings and the development of new sources of income.

    We all know that orchid growing is a new industry which will also bring in a

Column: 714

substantial income. In recent years we know that orchid cultivation is making great progress in rural areas. In our country, the history of orchid growing goes back to some 40 years. First, we must give credit to the authorities of the Botanic Gardens for their efforts on orchid growing and cultivation. Today many people have taken the cue and have since been growing orchids. Today we have many hybrids and varieties of quality orchids and we are well known for orchid cultivation. Even Hawaiian orchids are not comparable to ours now. Here the Primary Production Department has made great contributions. There is another aspect which we can be proud of. The Currency Board has chosen our orchids as the design for our currency notes.

    We also have a substantial amount of foreign exchange through the sale of orchids. If we can pay more attention to the development of orchid growing and a wider market, we will achieve even more. Therefore, I would like to suggest to the Minister concerned to set up an organisation to help the farmers in the marketing of orchids. According to a survey, Europeans and Americans are fond of orchids. For example, West Germany alone exports various kinds of flowers to various countries amounting to S$850 million per year. According to calculation, our total export of orchids is about US$6 to US$7 million, which is about 3 per cent of that of West Germany, which is our major market. In addition to this, there are other markets in West Europe. So we must intensively develop our export markets. I would suggest to the Minister to set up a special unit in the Primary Production Department and vest it with special duties to develop foreign markets for orchids and other kinds of flowers. We may then give more attention to our small farmers who plant flowers, so that they may be cared for and not be exploited by the middlemen. Next, we must extensively develop the methods of orchid planting. Though we are short of agricultural land, we still have a certain number of farms available for

Column: 715

the planting of orchids. This aspect of agriculture has many good points. (1) It does not lead to pollution of the air. (2) It has a beneficial contribution towards water. (3) We can earn much foreign exchange through the use of small capital investment on non-productive land and also utilising manpower to our benefit.

    So I hope the Minister will urge the Primary Production Department to develop this type of agriculture in order to get more foreign exchange for our country.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, because of the present inflation in Singapore, what steps are being taken to produce and to grow more crops locally? We cannot be self-sufficient in all types of food products; but we can be on some of them. What effort is being made to ensure that we are self-sufficient in poultry, pigs, eggs, fish, etc.? With proper farming, we can be self-sufficient in vegetables too. If those who live in houses with a garden are encouraged to grow vegetables, the inflated price of vegetables in the markets can be lowered considerably. Just to quote an instance, today at the Kandang Kerbau Market, the cost of two red chillies is 10 cents. Normally, you can get about 15 chillies for that price. Imagine the difference in real value.

    It would appear that our vegetable gardens are gradually being pushed out. What is the possibility of putting up vegetable gardens in flatted farms? Has the Minister thought about that? The roof-top of every housing block can be rented out to farmers to plant vegetables.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, some of my farmers in Potong Pasir are affected by urban renewal. It is strange that those farming some 0.5 hectare of land, or less, were not considered bona fide farmers by the Primary Production Department. Because

Column: 716

of this, they did not receive compensation normally paid to bona fide farmers, either in the form of cash, a free HDB flat, or alternative land to cultivate. I cannot fathom the rationale governing the Primary Production Department's determination of bona fide farmers and the necessity to differentiate farmers. Is one of the reasons that of avoiding paying compensation? I would be most pleased if the Hon. Minister could enlighten me.

    To my mind, a farmer is bona fide, whether he tills 0.5 or 1.0 hectare of land. He should not be discriminated against for being poorer. He sweats and toils, just tilling the land, perhaps harder, to provide Singaporeans with fresh, green vegetables. He has no other means of earning a living. The Primary Production Department merely confuses the poor hardworking farmer by telling him that he is not a bona fide farmer. How can he figure this out when, in actual fact, his occupation is farming? Imagine the farmer willing to assist the Government by moving out of the land, which provides him with his livelihood, to spend the rest of his days in the confines of a HDB flat, and yet he is denied the right of compensation as a farmer. Why is the Government denying him this right to live and enjoy the just rewards of his hard work by refusing to compensate him as a bona fide farmer?

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, I have an amendment* under this Head and since everybody is talking about agriculture, can I join in?
* The amendment reads as follows:

    (2) That the sum to be allocated for Head LK be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CA 1111.


    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, since I am the Member of Parliament of a constituency, half of which is rural, I feel that it is necessary for me to reflect in this House the poor plight of our farmers. I believe the Member for Chua Chu Kang will also have the same feeling, although he is not in the House yet.

Column: 717



    Sir, most of our farmers are rustic folks of great forbearance. They are law-abiding, hardworking, and their only aspiration in life is to earn three comfortable meals a day. They neither play with power, nor do they manipulate our market. So when there is a manipulation of prices of farm products in Singapore, the greatest victims of such manipulation are the farmers.

    Sir, when prices of farm produce fall, who extends a helping hand to the farmers? But when there is a slight rise in prices, everybody tries to keep it down. For example, a scheme was introduced to stop slaughtering pigs for two days a week, and there was even the lifting of import duty on frozen chicken and the lifting of the import ban of pigs from other countries. As a result of such measures, our farmers have been very hard hit.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the world seems to be unduly harsh and unfair to farmers in Singapore. We are very hard hit by imported inflation and we cannot do anything about it. The 20,000 farmers in Singapore are also affected because they have to pay more for their daily necessities. In the case of employed workers, they have the 9 per cent and $25 recommended by the National Wages Council. But who is there to look after the poor farmers and help them fight inflation? So it is fair that when there is a little rise in the prices of farm produce, attempts are made to suppress it.

    Sir, it is becoming increasingly difficult to engage in farming activities in Singapore because of the diminishing returns of farm land. Although a lot of land has been acquired from the farmers, they are resettled in a much smaller plot of land. Furthermore, the rate of compensation still remains the same, despite the increase in the cost of building construction and materials in recent years. This has also made it difficult for farmers affected by resettlement to build their own farms and farm-houses.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our labour shortage has also affected farmers because it is difficult for them to engage help on the

Column: 718

farm. So they will have to pay higher wages to engage farm help. This is another item that adds to their burden.

    Sir, furthermore there is the question of the rise in the price of animal feed. Animal feed dealers have not only increased the prices of their products but they have also asked for cash from the farmers instead of allowing them credit. Because of this difficulty, the cost of production has definitely gone up, and if no help is rendered to the poor farmers, I am afraid they will suffer in the end. Sir, if what is left of our agriculture cannot be developed or even continue to exist, it will be a great tragedy for Singapore because it will mean that all the consumers in Singapore will have to pay more for imported farm products. The situation will then be much worse.

    Sir, it is quite right that because of geographical limitation, we do not depend on farming and agriculture for a living. But it cannot be denied that farming activities are also an asset to our national wealth because they help to solve our unemployment problem on the one hand, and they help to balance the prices of farm products imported from overseas on the other hand. Without agricultural activities in our farms, we will have to pay at least 30 cents for an egg imported from abroad. Therefore, every assistance must be given to our farmers to enable them to increase their production, so that higher productivity will help to bring down prices and the cost of living in Singapore thereby helping our consumers.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our agriculture is now in great difficulties. It is only the Government that is in a position to revive agriculture which is declining in Singapore. I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Government to extend a helping hand to the development of our agriculture. It should not be allowed to swim or to sink by itself.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Member for Jurong in regard to his views on agriculture in Singapore.

Column: 719



    Sir, over the past one or two years, many countries in the world have suffered from food shortages. Worldwide inflation has affected all of us in Singapore, particularly those who depend on imported goods. The cost of living in Singapore has also risen because of this. In respect of food supply, the Primary Production Department has over the years encouraged farmers in Singapore to work hard and to help them with all kinds of farming aids. As a result we have been able to achieve self-sufficiency in the supply of pigs, chicken, and eggs. But because of the fantastic rise in the price of animal feed, the prices of farm products have also been affected. So if we had neglected our agricultural sector, our cost of living would have risen still higher, because we will then have to depend entirely on the importation of farm produce and other consumer goods as well. That would add further to what is already a heavy burden on our people. Sir, if this had happened we would have lost at least by way of foreign exchange. So the contribution made by our farmers cannot be denied.

    The next problem I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister is the question of change of employment of our farmers. We all know that most of our farmers in Singapore are in the age group of 40 to 50. Because of a change of circumstances, such as measures taken by the Government to protect our water resources which make it difficult for farmers to carry on their farming activities, then these farmers will have no choice but to change their employment. But with their limited qualification and experience, and age, it will be difficult for these old farmers to change their jobs. As a result, their livelihood will become problematic and, from the point of view of our national economy, that will also constitute a great loss of our manpower. Sir, it is my belief that our enlightened Government will not allow our small and medium-size farmers to sink or to swim by themselves, and every help will be given them.

    Mr Seah Mui Kok (Bukit Ho Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore has to import

Column: 720

a good number of agricultural products from neighbouring countries, and the prices of these agricultural products are rising higher and higher. In view of this fact, I am enquiring from the Hon. Minister whether he would care to make a feasibility study of using a few of our small neighbouring islands for agricultural farming. If it is feasible, the farmers will be interested. Could the Minister please give consideration?

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the banning of the importation of livestock from neighbouring countries on account of the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, there is little or no fresh beef for sale in many of our markets. We have to import most of our frozen meat from countries like New Zealand, Australia and the USA. The prices of frozen meat have increased considerably over the past year, thus contributing to the high cost of living. We are aware that there is a joint project between Singapore and Indonesia on Batam island where cattle is raised for eventual importation into Singapore. May I know from the Minister what is the total investment contributed by Singapore, and whether the cattle raised in this joint project will be sufficient to meet the needs of beef consumption in Singapore?

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, as Members have rested well over the week-end, they have come back afresh. Perhaps we should have carried on until 8 o'clock on Friday, but it is not my wish to silence them.

    In my reply, I shall go backwards and start with the Member for Toa Payoh, who has complained about the lack of fresh beef in the markets. This is obvious because there was an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease sometime back and, as a result, we had to slaughter about 400 head of cattle. There have also been complaints why we have stopped the import of cattle. The answer is obvious: it is because of the foot-and-mouth disease. Otherwise it will spread throughout Singapore.

Column: 721



    As for the project on Batam island, we have invested nothing. It is completely an Indonesian project with Australian assistance - Australian cattle. The cattle is already there. If it is imported into Singapore, Batam island will be used as a quarantine station. In other words, if the cattle there is free of the foot-and-mouth disease it can then come straight into Singapore and not necessarily into our quarantine station in Jurong. At the moment they are still breeding the cattle on Batam island. I do not think they have enough head of cattle for export to Singapore.

    As for the Member for Bukit Ho Swee, he wants to know why we do not farm on the islands. There are already some farmers in Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong. But it is not easy to get the farmers from the main island to farm on the other islands around Singapore because it means transporting the products across the sea. This takes time and money.

    The Member for Jurong made his usual speech on the Budget. Can I deal with one point that was raised by him, and that is, the question of the lifting of quota on chickens? This was done in order to bring the price down. But this was not done by my Ministry because we are not in charge of the quota. However, we have warned the Ministry of Finance of the dangers of leaving that quota too long. Our prime concern, like the Member for Jurong, is the protection of our farmers. Having seen the poultry industry grow to such a strong position that we export chickens and eggs - this was not easily done, but done over many years - we are naturally conscious to see that this industry is not affected by foreign competition. We have already warned the Ministry of Finance of these dangers and we are keeping a finger on it.

    The Member for Potong Pasir talked about bona fide farmers. If someone keeps a few chickens and a pig in his backyard for the Chinese New Year or Christmas, that does not make him a bona fide farmer, especially if he works in Jurong or drives a taxi. By a "bona

Column: 722

fide farmer", we mean a farmer who genuinely does farming. There are, of course, genuine or bona fide farmers. But there are also people who do farming part-time just to have eggs for breakfast or chicken for the week-end. They do not depend on farming completely as a means of subsistence, and that is why we say they are not bona fide farmers.

    The Member for Anson wants the Primary Production Department to grow vegetables on the roof-tops of Housing Board flats. It is an ingenious idea, but it has practical difficulties. The Member for Sembawang wants the Primary Production Department to find a market for orchids. There are already several orchid exporters in Singapore who have their contacts overseas, and hence the export of orchids brings in considerable foreign exchange. But it is not for the Primary Production Department to compete with these firms. No one is prevented from exporting orchids if he can find the right contacts overseas. As for fishing, there is a Fisheries Research Station at Changi and I would be happy to show the Member around. If he goes there he will see that fish are reared. There are also the giant fresh water prawns. The young fish and prawns are sold to the farmers or fishermen for breeding.

    Every year the Primary Production Department is asked to help farmers. Well, it does help them. But there is a shortage of land in Singapore, and there are priorities. The town itself is expanding and with the creation of new towns like Toa Payoh, Queenstown and Woodlands, there is less land for farming. But the Department is not asleep. It has the Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory at Kampung Java which provides routine diagnosis of pigs and poultry which have died. It finds out what is wrong and tells the farmers. Specific disease control schemes are conducted by the Primary Production Department. There is also the control of pullorum disease in poultry, and swine brucellosis in pigs, a disease which causes abortions in fertility, resulting in loss of production. We have a scheme which enables farms to get rid of this

Column: 723

disease. We have also a free swine fever vaccination service, a poultry vaccination service, a plant protection service, and there are 10 treatment centres strategically located throughout the island providing treatment services to pig and poultry farmers on the island. We even have training facilities and both ad hoc training and organised training are conducted by the Department to enable farmers to learn more recent techniques on farming, breeding and disease control. The Farm School at Sembawang is one example of organised training conducted by the Department, it runs a one-year residential course and trainees can choose one of three subjects, animal husbandry, horticulture or fish culture for specialisation. The school has turned out 173 graduates who are now either managing their own farms or gainfully employed in the primary production sector.

    Members may be interested to know that the Department has successfully experimented with the cultivation of straw mushroom, and yields of up to 15 per cent of the weight of the growing medium have been obtained. The Department has also run a number of courses for the public, and there are now a few commercial farms producing straw mushrooms. A limiting factor to this development is the lack of padi-straws, the medium used for cultivating the mushroom. But the Department is now experimenting with substitutes, such as sawdust, cotton waste, coconut fibre and paper waste. The results are inconclusive.

    As for hydroponics, the Department has successfully experimented with the cultivation of high value crops, such as capsicum, under this system. Yields of up to one pound per plant per crop may be obtained, and with three crops in a year. The Department is now extending its experiments to leafy vegetables, and these have shown encouraging results. Yields are much higher than those produced from the conventional methods of cultivation. The Department is now intensifying its efforts to transmit its findings to the private sector.

    As for the fishing port at Jurong, Members will remember the opposition

Column: 724

we met when the port was first opened and the fishmongers had to shift to Jurong. But I am happy to say that, since its opening in 1969, an increasing number of fishing vessels have made use of the port facilities. The number of fishing vessels visiting the port in 1973 was only 387, and last year numbered 659. The fishing port has attracted fishing vessels not only from our own Republic but also those from Japan, Taiwan, Korea and Russia. About 2,000 local fishermen and 4,000 fish merchants and retailers make use of the market facilities. Members will be interested to know too that seven factories are now in production, producing filleted fish meat and fish meal for animal feed.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Baptist: Sir, I was not talking about one pig, two chickens and three ducks. I was actually not talking about animal farming at all. I was talking about vegetable farming, not on just one square metre of land but about 0.5 hectare of land tilled by the farmers in Potong Pasir. They are not considered bona fide farmers although vegetable farming is their only means of livelihood, and in addition licences were issued to them by the Primary Production Department. I was wondering whether the Minister could enlighten me as to why they are not receiving any compensation as farmers.

    Mr Barker: Sir, anyone who is paid compensation must be a bona fide farmer. If he grows vegetables and just depends on that for his living, then I would say he is a bona fide farmer. If there are cases of that nature in Potong Pasir, perhaps the Member could give me specific instances and I will look into the matter.

    I referred to pigs and poultry because that is the practice in Singapore. The farmers do not only grow vegetables; they have chickens and pigs, and sometimes even a taxi too.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee: Sir, on the Batam island project, in view of the likelihood of a continuing ban on the importation of cattle from neighbouring countries, which consequently leads to a

Column: 725

shortage of beef, does the Minister consider that it would be of mutual advantage to both Indonesia and Singapore if we were to enter into a similar project in the form of regional aid in veterinary science and animal husbandry, possibly under the auspices of ASEAN?
